description: From Middle French combiner, from Late Latin combīnāre, present active infinitive of combīnō (“unite, yoke together”), from Latin con- (“together”) + bīnī (“two by two”).

examples: We can't finish harvesting because our combine is stuck in the mud.

entries.meaning: Especially, a joint enterprise of whatever legal form for a purpose of business or in any way promoting the interests of the participants, sometimes with monopolistic or fraudulent intentions.
examples: The telecom companies were accused of having formed an illegal combine in order to hike up the network charges.

entries.meaning: An industrial conglomeration in a socialist country, particularly in the former Soviet bloc.
(art) An artwork falling between painting and sculpture, having objects embedded into a painted surface.
(American football) A Test match in which applicants play in the hope of earning a position on a professional football team.

verbs.description: combine (third-person singular simple present combines, present participle combining, simple past and past participle combined)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To bring (two or more things or activities) together; to unite.
examples: Combine the milk and the hot water in a large bowl.   I'm combining business and pleasure on this trip.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To have two or more things or properties that function together.
examples: Joe combines the intelligence of a rock with the honesty of a politician.

entries.meaning: (card games) In the game of casino, to play a card which will take two or more cards whose aggregate number of pips equals those of the card played.
(obsolete) To bind; to hold by a moral tie.
